text: <@U01LM3R61HV> it was a problem with compiling to PDF: having \usage in the text broke the compilation. Should be fixed by putting in backquotes - I've just made a commit that works locally.

text: <@U01KXU8UNRX> I merged in the Windows and Fedora PRs. I don't think you made the edits regarding the prequisites as we discussed yesterday, but maybe that is easier to do on from a fresh start after the merges - and perhaps to do a final read-through of the whole chapter to see if there are any minor edits required.

text:
There are two issues:

1. Change *existing links* from <https://developer.r-project.org/Blog/public/> to <https://blog.r-project.org/> - no change in the text required, just search and replace to update the hyperlinks. This needs fixing now as part of #30.
2. Add a link to the translations blog post: <https://blog.r-project.org/2022/07/25/r-can-use-your-help-translating-r-messages/index.html>. This is the part that could be done when documenting weblate as we would need to put the link in context somehow.

text:
I've finished the case study: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/wiki/GSOD-2022-Case-Study>. If you have time to read it through before 18:00 UTC tomorrow, feel free to correct any issues you see.

I won't read it again, but I have submitted the final form to Google with a link to this case study.

text:
Great summary of all the work done. Thanks to all the team!
One question I have about the visitor counts is how much was driven by myself or other contributors just comparing with previous versions or checking other chapters to cross-reference sections.
About the timeline, I am sorry I cannot promise to finish the instructions on installing from source on macOS. I will be around in case I can help anyone taking up the task.
I reviewed the issues in the rdevguide and I found that I never checked how to build the manuals without building R (comment in <https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/pull/66#discussion_r982119195> ) Maybe that comment could be left for later too?
